questions.question: Which of the following statements is incorrect about tonsils?

options.A: Bed of the tonsil is formed by the superior constrictor and styloglossus muscles.
options.B: It is covered by keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium on the medial surface.
options.C: Crypta magna is a remnant of the ventral part of second pharyngeal pouch.
options.D: A capsule covers the lateral surface of the tonsils.

questions.explanation: The medial surface of the tonsil is covered by non-keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium.468Tonsils are ovoid masses of lymphoid tissue situated in the lateral wall of the oropharynx betweenthe anterior and posterior pillars.The medial surface of the tonsil is covered in 12-15 crypts. Crypta magna or intratonsillar cleft isthe largest & deepest of the crypts. It is situated near the upper part of the tonsil andrepresents the ventral part of the second pharyngeal pouch.The lateral surface of the tonsil presents a well-defined fibrous capsule.The bed of the tonsil is formed by the superior constrictor and styloglossus muscles.

questions.question: At what age do the tonsils attain their maximum size?
questions.explanation: The growth of tonsils is rapid around the age of 5-6 years of age and usually reaches theirmaximum size by 12 years of age.Tonsillar involution begins at puberty when the reactive lymphoid tissue begins to atrophy, and byold age, only a little tonsillar lymphoid tissue remains.

questions.question: A patient diagnosed with oral carcinoma was referred to the ENT department for evaluation.While examining the oral cavity, the consultant asked you to examine the ENT surgeon'sgraveyard to check for any induration or ulcers. What is the area being referred to here?
questions.explanation: The area referred to here is the tonsillolingual sulcus which is known as the graveyard of ENTsurgeons.The palatine tonsil is separated from the tongue by a sulcus called the tonsillolingual sulcus,which may be the seat of carcinoma. This area is easily missed during oral examination henceknown as the graveyard of ENT surgeons.

questions.question: Which of the following is the main arterial supply of palatine tonsils?

options.A: Tonsillar branch of the facial artery
options.B: Descending palatine branch of maxillary artery460
options.D: Ascending palatine branch of facial artery

questions.explanation: Tonsillolingual sulcusOMARROWEpiglottis-TonsilTonsillolingualsulcusForamencaecumOW469The main arterial supply of tonsil is by the tonsillar branch of the facial artery.Five arteries supply the tonsil:•• Tonsillar branch of the facial artery (the main artery)• Ascending palatine branch of the facial artery• Ascending pharyngeal branch of the external carotid artery•• Dorsal lingual branches of the lingual artery•Descending palatine branches of the maxillary arteryAscendingArterial Supply of Tonsilpharyngeal arteryMaxillary arteryDescendingpalatine arteryTonsillar branchesof ascendingpharyngeal arteyAscendingpalatine arteryTonsillar arteryFacial arteryDorsal linguaebranchesLingual arteryExternal carotidarteryOMARROW

questions.question: You are the second-year ENT resident performing a tonsillectomy in a patient with chronic tonsillitis. While creating a dissection plane between the capsule and the bed of the tonsil, you accidentally deepened the incision, injuring the tonsillar bed. Which of the following structures is least likely to be injured?
questions.explanation: The lateral pterygoid muscle is not related to the bed of the tonsil and is the least likely structure to be injured in this scenario. The bed of the tonsil is formed by the superior constrictor and styloglossus muscles. The lower fossa is related to: the glossopharyngeal nerve and the styloid process. Outside the superior constrictor, the tonsil is related to: the facial artery, the submandibular salivary gland, the posterior belly of the digastric muscle, the medial pterygoid muscle, and the angle of the mandible.

questions.question: A 7-year-old child was brought to the hospital by his mother with complaints of a sore throat,earache, and pain on swallowing for three days. On examination, the tonsils were enlargedand hyperaemic. Which of the following is the most common organism implicated in thiscondition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute tonsillitis. The most common organism causingacute tonsillitis in children is ẞ hemolytic streptococcus.Other causative organisms include:•Staphylococcus aureus•Streptococcus pneumoniae•Haemophilus influenzae

questions.question: A young lady presents to the ENT OPD with the finding shown below. Which of the following lymph nodes will primarily enlarge in this condition?
questions.explanation: The image shows purulent inflammation of the tonsils suggestive of acute tonsillitis. Jugulo-digastric (tonsillar) lymph nodes will primarily enlarge in this condition. The lymphatics from the palatine tonsils pierce the superior constrictor muscle and primarily drain into the upper deep cervical nodes (level II), particularly the jugulo-digastric (tonsillar) nodes situated below the angle of the mandible. So, it is the most likely group of lymph nodes to enlarge in case of acute tonsillitis.

questions.question: A middle-aged man presented with a history of fever, sore throat, and dysphagia for threedays. Which of the following variants is not expected to be seen on oral examination?
questions.explanation: The patient's history is suggestive of acute tonsillitis. The fibroid variety is a type of chronictonsillitis and is not expected to be seen in this case.471Depending on the pathology within the tonsillar tissue, acute tonsillitis can be classified into thefollowing types:• Acute catarrhal or superficial tonsillitis: Here tonsillitis is a part of generalized pharyngitis and isprimarily seen in viral infections.•Acute follicular tonsillitis: The infection spreads into the crypts, which become filled withpurulent material, presenting at the openings of crypts as yellowish spots..Acute parenchymatous tonsillitis: Here tonsil substance is affected. Tonsil is uniformly enlargedand red.• Acute membranous tonsillitis: It is a stage ahead of acute follicular tonsillitis when exudationfrom the crypts coalesces to form a membrane on the surface of the tonsil.Types of chronic tonsillitis:• Chronic follicular tonsillitis• Chronic parenchymal tonsillitis• Chronic fibroid tonsillitis

questions.question: An anxious mother brought her 4-year-old-child to the hospital with complaints of suddenonset fever and refusal to eat. On examination, the given finding was noted and he wasstarted on analgesics and antibiotics. Which among the following is not a known complicationof this condition?462
questions.explanation: The given clinical vignette is suggestive of acute tonsillitis. Excessive bleeding is not a knowncomplication of this condition.Complications of acute tonsillitis:•⚫ Chronic tonsillitis - chronic infection may persist in lymphoid follicles of the tonsil in the form ofmicroabscesses•⚫ Peritonsillar abscess• Parapharyngeal abscess• Cervical abscess due to suppuration of jugulodigastric lymph nodes• Acute otitis media•Rheumatic fever - often seen in association with tonsillitis due to group A ẞ-hemolyticstreptococci• Acute glomerulonephritis (rare)•Subacute bacterial endocarditis - acute tonsillitis in a patient with valvular heart disease may becomplicated by endocarditis. It is usually due to Streptococcus viridans infection

questions.question: Which of the following nerves is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis?
questions.explanation: The tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) is responsible for referredotalgia from tonsillitis.472The tonsils and tonsillar fossa are supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve. The glossopharyngealnerve and the styloid process lie in relation to the lower part of the tonsillar fossa. Therefore, anyirritation or pain can be referred to the ear along the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal(Jacobson's) nerve.Causes of referred otalgia via the glossopharyngeal nerve include acute pharyngitis, tonsillitis,peritonsillar abscess, post-tonsillectomy, foreign bodies embedded in the base of the tongue ortonsillar area and an elongated styloid process (Eagle's syndrome).The ear receives extensive sensory innervation via four cranial nerves (V, VII, IX, and X) and twospinal segments (C2 and C3).The image below shows the anatomic relations of the tonsil and tonsillar bed:Relations of tonsil-Tonsillar bed10Palatine tonsilLoose areolar tissue with paratonsillar veinPharyngobasilar fasciaSuperior constrictor muscleStyloglossusBuccopharyngeal fasciaFacial arteryGlossopharyngeal nerveSubmandibular glandMedial pterygoidAngle of mandible©MARROW

questions.question: A 15-year-old girl presented to the ENT surgeon with a history of loud snoring, restless sleepleading to daytime somnolence, and poor academic performance. Her medical history wasunremarkable, except for recurrent episodes of acute tonsillitis. Which of the following typesof tonsillitis may be implicated in this condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical presentation is suggestive of obstructive sleep apnea syndrome (OSAS)secondary to chronic parenchymatous tonsillitis.In parenchymatous tonsillitis, the tonsils grow very large following repeated attacks of acutetonsillitis and lead to obstructive symptoms, including OSAS.Types of chronic tonsillitis:• Chronic follicular tonsillitis- tonsillar crypts are full of infected cheesy material, which shows onthe surface as yellowish spots.•Chronic parenchymatous tonsillitis- there is hyperplasia of lymphoid tissue. Tonsils are verymuch enlarged and may interfere with speech, deglutition, and respiration. Attacks of sleepapnoea may occur. Long-standing cases develop features of cor pulmonale.• Chronic fibroid tonsillitis- tonsils are tiny but infected, with a history of repeated sore throats.473Chronic parenchymatous tonsillitisOMARROW

questions.question: You are an intern posted in the ENT department working up a case of chronic folliculartonsillitis. Which of the following clinical signs would you not expect to see in this patient onexamining the oral cavity?
questions.explanation: Müller's sign is the pulsation of uvula during systole seen in aortic regurgitation. It is not seen inpatients with chronic tonsillitis.The classical signs of chronic tonsillitis are:•⚫ Irwin-Moore sign- tonsils are tiny, but pressure on the anterior pillar expresses frank pus orcheesy material.• Bluish Flushing of anterior pillars compared to the rest of the pharyngeal mucosa is a vital signof chronic tonsillar infection.•Enlargement of jugulo-digastric lymph nodes even in the absence of acute infection is a reliablesign of chronic tonsillitis. During acute attacks, the nodes enlarge further and become tender.

questions.question: An ENT junior resident observed a symptomless yellowish swelling over the tonsil when hewas examining a patient for a buccal sore. The swelling was easily drained. What is the likelydiagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a tonsillar cyst. It is a condition due to blockage of atonsillar crypt and appears as a yellowish swelling over the tonsil. Very often, it is symptomlessand can be easily drained.Option A: Intratonsillar abscess is an accumulation of pus within the substance of the tonsil. Itusually follows a blockage of the opening of the crypt in acute follicular tonsillitis. There is markedlocal pain and dysphagia. Tonsil appears swollen and red.Option B: Tonsilloliths (calculus of the tonsil) are seen in chronic tonsillitis when its crypt isblocked with retention of debris. Inorganic salts of calcium and magnesium are then depositedleading to the formation of a stone. It may gradually enlarge and then ulcerate through the tonsil.It generally causes local discomfort or foreign body sensation.474Option D: In follicular tonsillitis, purulent material is present at the opening of the crypts asyellow dots. It presents with fever, dysphagia, and sore throat.

questions.question: On examining the oral cavity of a patient who presented with fever and a sore throat, younotice a greyish-white membrane over the tonsils. Which of the following conditions wouldyou not consider as a differential diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Ludwig's angina is not associated with the formation of a grey-white membrane. It ischaracterized by rapidly spreading infection of the sublingual space initially and later thesubmaxillary space, often dentogenic in origin.D/D for membrane over tonsil:••Streptococcus & other pyogenic organismsDiphtheria• Infectious mononucleosis• Vincent's angina• Leukemia• Candida•Agranulocytosis•Malignancy• Apthous ulcer•• Traumatic ulcer

questions.question: 464Which of the following organisms is implicated in Vincent's angina?
questions.explanation: Vincent's angina is caused by fusiform bacilli and spirochaetes, namely Bacillus fusiformisand Borrelia vincenti.The condition presents with low-grade fever and sore throat, and a membrane over the tonsil. Themembrane is easily removed to reveal irregular ulcers over the tonsil. Throat swab will show boththe organisms typical of the disease, namely fusiform bacilli and spirochaetes.

questions.question: A worried mother brought her 6-year-old unimmunized child to the ER with complaints of fever, cough, and shortness of breath. On examination, a pseudomembrane was noted in the oral cavity along with the neck finding as shown in the image. Which of the following statements is true regarding the membrane observed?

options.B: Firmly adherent and bleeds on removal

questions.explanation: The given clinical history and bull-neck appearance (image) point to the diagnosis of diphtheria. The diphtheritic membrane is firmly adherent and bleeds on removal. A greyish-white membrane forms over the tonsils in the oropharynx and spreads to the soft palate and posterior pharyngeal wall. The membrane in diphtheria extends beyond the tonsils onto the soft palate and is dirty grey. It is adherent, and its removal leaves a bleeding surface. In the larynx, the diphtheritic membrane may cause airway obstruction. Cervical lymph nodes, particularly the jugulodigastric, become enlarged and tender, sometimes presenting a bull-neck appearance. The patient is ill and toxaemic, but fever seldom rises above 38°C.

questions.question: Which of the following complications would you not expect to see in a patient diagnosed withdiphtheria?
questions.explanation: Hard palate paralysis is not seen in diphtheria.The exotoxin produced by C. diphtheriae is toxic to the heart and nerves. It causes:• Myocarditis• Cardiac arrhythmias•Acute circulatory failureNeurological complications include paralysis of the soft-palate, diaphragm, and ocular muscles. Inthe larynx, the diphtheric membrane may cause airway obstruction.

questions.question: Following finding was noted in a patient who presented with difficulty breathing and abull-neck appearance. Which of the following statements is true regarding the treatment ofthis patient?

options.A: Treatment is started after the culture comes positive
options.D: Sensitivity to antitoxin should be tested prior to therapy

questions.explanation: The pseudomembrane on oral examination and bull neck appearance is characteristic ofdiphtheria. Sensitivity to diphtheria antitoxin is common and should be tested prior to theinitiation of therapy.Treatment is started on clinical suspicion without waiting for the culture report. The aim is toneutralize the free exotoxin still circulating in the blood and to kill the organisms producing thisexotoxin.Antitoxins:• Dose- based on the site involved, duration, and severity of the disease•If < 48 hours or just confined to tonsils: 20,000-40,000 units••If > 48 hours or extensive membrane: 80,000–120,000 units• Given by i.v. infusion in saline in about 60 min• Sensitivity tested by a conjunctival or intracutaneous test with diluted antitoxin• If a hypersensitivity reaction occurs, desensitization should be doneAntibiotics:•Benzyl penicillin 600 mg 6 hourly for 7 days⚫ Erythromycin is used in penicillin-sensitive individuals (500 mg 6 hourly orally)•

questions.question: Which of the following cases cannot be posted for an elective tonsillectomy?

options.B: A young adult with chronic tonsillitis refractory to treatment
options.C: A patient with unilateral enlargement of tonsil with suspected malignancy
options.D: A middle-aged man with recurrent quinsy466

questions.explanation: 476Acute tonsillitis is a contraindication for tonsillectomy and hence, cannot be posted for electivesurgery.Acute tonsillitis or any upper respiratory tract infection is a contraindication for tonsillectomysince there is an increased chance of hemorrhage and sepsis.Indications of tonsillectomy are:• Recurrent episodes of acute tonsillitis - most common indicationSeven or more episodes in 1 year, orFive episodes per year for 2 years, orThree episodes per year for 3 years, orTwo weeks or more of lost school or work in 1 year• Febrile seizures due to fever in tonsillitis• Peritonsillar abscess (quinsy) - recurrent episodes in adults and a single episode in children• Hypertrophy of tonsils causing airway obstruction, difficulty in deglutition, interference withspeech•• Unilateral enlargement of tonsil with suspicion of malignancyChronic tonsillitis with bad taste or halitosis which is unresponsive to medical treatment(relative indication)

questions.question: Which of the following is not a contraindication to perform a tonsillectomy?
questions.explanation: Diphtheria and streptococcal carriers are relative indications for tonsillectomy and the surgery can be safely performed in patients presenting with the same. Contraindications for tonsillectomy: Haemoglobin level less than 10 g%. Presence of acute infection in the upper respiratory tract, even acute tonsillitis. Bleeding is more in the presence of acute infection. Children under 3 years of age. Overt or submucous cleft palate. Bleeding disorders, e.g. leukaemia, purpura, aplastic anaemia or haemophilia. At the time of an epidemic of polio. Uncontrolled systemic disease, e.g. diabetes, cardiac disease, hypertension or asthma. Tonsillectomy is avoided during the period of menses.

questions.question: A patient develops bleeding from the surgical site five hours after an elective tonsillectomy.Which among the following would best describe the condition?
questions.explanation: 477Bleeding from the surgical site within a period of 24 hours is categorised as a reactionaryhaemorrhage.Primary haemorrhage -occurs at the time of operation.Secondary haemorrhage - usually seen between the fifth to tenth postoperative days.

questions.question: While preparing for a procedure, the patient was kept in a specific position as depicted in theimage. In which of the following procedures is this position not adopted?MARROW
questions.explanation: The given image shows Rose's position and it is not a suitable position to perform a directlaryngoscopy. The barking-dog position is used for direct laryngoscopy.Rose's position: The patient lies supine with head extended by placing a pillow under theshoulders. It is followed in adenoidectomy, tonsillectomy, and tracheostomy.MARROWOMARROWBarking-dog position: Patient lies supine. The Head is elevated by 10-15 cm by placing a pillowunder the occiput or raising the operation table's head flap. The neck is flexed on the thorax andthe head is extended on the atlanto-occipital joint.47827MOMARROW479
